comments.commentBody: McCarthyism hurt a lot of innocent people.  How has anyone been hurt in this case?   What civil liberties have been destroyed?

Mr. Pollack: This has been going on since 1978. I hate it myself. The other day I got a ticket because I didn't come to a full stop when making a right hand turn (signal on). I slowed down and sort of rolled around the corner at the speed of 16 mph. How was I found out? That little camera above.

Perhaps someone out there has an answer, but I haven't seen or heard one yet.

Laws are not necessarily lawful. Using FISA and/or hiding behind nondisclosure and other secretive procedures mocks the rule of law itself. Obama has soiled the Constitution he was sworn to uphold. This is worse than McCarthyism because more sweeping in intent and possessing the technological means for conducting surveillance.

Obamacare is not an exception- it only proves what we've already known about the Republicans. What the Republicans suggest and do borders a national disgrace and a loss of sanity on their part- the fact that they're allow to continue to do this and without repercussion is an even bigger disgrace on the people they're representing. Is this how they expect their elected representatives to govern?

This conduct reaches a new level of being dumbstruck- now the Republicans are going full throttle in not only denying care, but also hurting their constituents? It is a great disappointment to witness the resistance of the GOP to the Affordable Care Act. There is zero logic in their opposition. They will benefit, as we all will, if we live in a healthy society. A society that has access to excellent healthcare.

It is not in the interests of the fortunate to be surrounded by untreated illness carried by people who take care of our homes, our elderly, our children, & prepare our food.

comments.commentBody: It is not necessary to smoke cannabis. You can gobble it.
No one is claiming total harmlessness, but marijuana is less harmless that a ten year prison sentence, don't you think?

Marijuana will be very profitable. Savvy individuals in the "prison industrial" complex have probably already hedged their bets by investing. The idea that smoking marijuana is harmless is a malignant delusion. It is a highly aromatic herb. Burning any aromatic herb at a relatively low temperature produces aromatized benzene rings. That is the carcinogen in cigarette smoke. It is unvarnished rationalization and willful self delusion to claim that this will not prove to be the case with marijuana. The one study large enough to yield reliable data was in New Zealand and it suggested that one, yes one marijuana cigarette was as carcinogenic as a package of unfiltered tobacco cigarettes. As we gather data from legal smokers the harm will become apparent. Denying harm now is as arrogant as defending tobacco smoking seventy five years ago. Those who defended smoking then did not have any models to justify caution and the shorter lifespans hid the harm since most of the harm of smoking does not appear for thirty five years. Those claiming harmlessness for marijuana have the model of the tobacco companies before them and should practice a respectful caution.
That said, most recreational drugs should be legalized taxed and regulated and made available, perhaps under medical supervision in the case of some of the more dangerous and addictive ones. If we haven't learned not to criminalize victimless personal behavior by now we will never learn anything.

The "Oh heavens the sky is falling! Our democracy is destroyed!" quality of most of these comments is unrealistic, for a couple of reasons.

The private sector has been collecting, using and abusing large quantities of data about Americans for years, in ways which affect us as much if not more than anything the U.S. Government does with security data. Most of the people expressing such high dudgeon here about the government collecting data have uttered nary a peep about the private sector doing so. While there may be good arguments for reigning in the power of the government in this regard, I for one trust the federal government, and President Obama and Attorney General Holder, far more than I trust the private sector in terms of not abusing the data which has been collected. Our personal privacy has been destroyed -- but it was destroyed by the private sector's collection, use and abuse of data for commercial reasons long before the U.S. Government got into the act for security reasons, and hardly anybody seems to have noticed or cared.

The Government appears to collect all of this data to have it ready to hand for analysis when clues surface during terrorism investigations. If agencies obtain intelligence that X is associated with a terrorist organization and may be planning an attack against the United States, the agencies don't have to wait for issuance of and compliance with a subpoena -- they already have the data and can analyze it immediately.

"The right of the people to be secure in their persons, houses, papers, and effects, against unreasonable searches and seizures, shall not be violated, and no warrants shall issue, but upon probable cause, supported by oath or affirmation, and particularly describing the place to be searched, and the persons or things to be seized." --Fourth Amendment, ratified 1787

I would argue that the listings of "papers and effects" refers not just to individual wallets, goods and books, but also to letters of correspondence. The modern descendants of the letter of old are the telephone calls, emails, texts and tweets. The Supreme and lesser Courts have not done enough to defend our right to privacy.

Speaking as someone who votes Democratic far more often than not, I am appalled by both President Obama's use of this massive information grab done without probable cause and Senator Feinstein's defense of this information grab--probable cause is that "someone might become a terrorist? Please don't insult my intelligence. I want Senator Feinstein off the Intelligence Committee and I want President Obama to start using his constitutional law chops to actually support and defend the Constitution instead of shredding it.

Then again, since this was primarily started by Republicans back under Bush, they shouldn't be pointing fingers only because a Democrat is doing it now.

I respectfully disagree. To the extent that I try to lead an exemplary life, I don't care if the government has all my phone records or even if they record every word of every phone conversation. The only objection that I might have is that they would be wasting time and taxpayer dollars on activities that would benefit nobody. But that is not true of people using phone contacts to plot acts of terrorism or other criminal acts.

There may actually be a way that many people could benefit by having their phone records logged by the government -- to be used as evidence against companies that illegally make unsolicited advertising calls. A filing under the Freedom of Information Act might actually be cheaper than a request for the same information from one's telephone carrier.

Leo Toribio
Pittsburgh, PA

This latest example of overreach, while not a surprise, is truly outrageous, and may finally beg the question to a broad cross-section of the electorate: Has our government turned against us? Perhaps now we can try answering this question honestly. We're certainly ripe for it, considering that we're generally disgruntled, on all sides, and perhaps more broadly attuned the notion that our government operates under a vast cover of secrecy, often in opposition to the spirit of our Republic, and against the will of the people.
But we are kept on such wobbly footing by our government and the media today, anxious as they are to disguise the truth and stoke argument, that we find ourselves grasping about for a coherent narrative to make sense of our government's actions and the very real anger we feel. This, in concert with a total lack of moral leadership, causes us to line up with our tribes to find somewhere (else) to place blame, twisting the truth even to ourselves when we should be debating honestly and in good faith on this and many other issues, too numerous to mention. We've lost our way when we allow ourselves to be duped in the name of National Security (not to mention good ratings and ad revenue) while the rule of law has been twisted beyond all recognition. A sense of justice is long overdue.
Maybe now we will start to deal honestly with what we've become - an empire under surveillance.

I am loathe to admit this, since I actively supported President Obama in two elections and truly believed in his integrity. But either he has been lying to us all along or he is not the one actually calling the shots.

Perhaps the military-industrial complex that Dwight Eisenhower warned of so many years ago is actually the driving force behind our government, forever chasing profit and looking for new ways to drum up fear. How else can you explain this blatant violation of citizen privacy?

Mr. President, I am profoundly disappointed. And I simply do not believe that the supposed terrorist threat of a handful of poor, disgruntled Muslims is enough to warrant this flagrant abuse of our Constitutional protections.

American exceptionalism, my bum. We are no better than a police state if this is what passes for democracy & freedom these days.
